chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Most people can agree the presidential election rules should reward broad national support, keep states meaningfully involved, and make the winner feel legitimate to as many voters as possible. A pragmatic middle path is to keep the Electoral College but curb its biggest distortions by ending winner-take-all, expanding the House to better match population, and requiring electors to follow the state’s certified results under uniform recount and certification standards. If those steps still leave persistent popular-vote mismatches, an interstate compact or constitutional amendment could be considered with clear thresholds and transition rules to protect stability.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Even when we disagree about keeping or replacing the Electoral College, many of us want a system where more voters matter and the outcome tracks voter intent without sacrificing stability or a meaningful role for states. A practical compromise is to keep the constitutional framework but curb winner-take-all by allocating electors proportionally or by district with strong anti-gerrymandering safeguards, alongside clear national standards for access, counting, audits, and certification. We can also evaluate a carefully designed popular-vote mechanism (such as an interstate compact with uniform recount thresholds and transition rules) against shared goals of legitimacy, regional coalition-building, and public trust.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Even when we disagree about keeping or replacing the Electoral College, many of us want a president chosen by rules that feel fair to individual voters and still encourage candidates to compete beyond a few swing states. A workable middle path is to keep state-run elections but end winner-take-all by allocating electors proportionally (or by district with strong anti-gerrymandering protections), paired with clear national standards for ballot access, counting, audits, and recount triggers. We can also add a backstop—such as a national popular-vote compact or automatic runoff/RCV in close races—so the final outcome tracks voter preference while preserving stability and regional balance.
